title: Before 1 January 2020, will either SpaceX or Boeing launch its first crewed space mission?

After a delay of almost two years, SpaceX’s Crew Dragon might carry its first astronauts to the International Space Station (ISS) as soon a January or February of next year.
https://www.firstpost.com/tech/science/spacexs-crew-dragon-could-launch-nasa-astronauts-into-space-as-soon-as-early-next-year-7519811.html NASA confirmed the aviation and aerospace company Boeing is pushing forward with their new Starliner crew capsule, which aims to ferry astronauts to the International Space Station (ISS) in 2020. But before the craft is deemed fit to carry a crew, it still must clear two critical tests. The first test — the Pad Abort Test — will ensure the craft's escape system works as expected during an emergency on the launch pad. The test is set to take place on November 4 at White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico. The next test — the Orbital Flight Test — is scheduled for December 17, which is when Starliner will venture to the ISS for about a week. There will be no crew aboard Starliner during this test, but it will mark the first time the capsule makes it to orbit and docks with the ISS.
https://astronomy.com/news/2019/10/boeing-starliner-gears-up-for-crewed-trip-to-iss-with-two-new-test-dates Neither is even remotely credible for a 1 Jan 2020 date, not having passed the milestones set by NASA,. If they do so on schedule this prediction will be revised.
As it's too late in the year.

After a public spat between NASA and SpaceX [1], it is difficult to see a path forward of a Crew Dragon launch this year. In early October, Elon Musk announced that the Crew Dragon could launch in 3 to 4 months [2].  These dates put the earliest possible crewed launch at the end of December.  This timeline is in line with the tentative schedule of an abort test not earlier than November 23 [3], assuming a successful abort test and SpaceX (and NASA) can have a turnaround (analyze the test data and go through the approval processes) in a month.  While SpaceX can work efficiently (rockets and capsule arrived in Florida launching site already [4]), it is unlikely that NASA can do it this fast.   I am throwing in my towel for a crewed launch this year for SpaceX.  My failure in this question is underestimating the time required for SpaceX and NASA, two organizations with different corporate cultures, working together. Previous prediction: assume a 10 (plus minus 3) months delay between first unmanned and manned test of a capsule, which is actually compatible with the history of space exploration (if we remove the shuttle, which is reusable and thus particularly complex). New line of thought: the original planner manned flight of Space X has been already delayed by 4-5 months. One needs only a 1.5 month delay to leave it after 1st of January. Assuming this delay to be representative, I could assume a 50% probability of the test happening within 4-5 months of the planned date and another 50% prob that it a similar delay could happen again, giving a 15-19% probability of failing the deadline. Notice that I am being really sloppy, but well... Averaging the two (also sloppy), I got a 26-28% prob that Space X will make it.

Boeing has problems across its organization. We see that from the 737 MAX crashes, the hidden software rollout, the re-certification to fly now speculated for 2020, the inability to communicate on the matter from the C-suite, and a long-standing (to some) sense of pushing stock price over engineering---"sales, sales, sales".  We now know in the general press that the very dated  737 fuselage has in-flight flaws when powered with newer engines (thus the need for software workarounds in the 737 MAX).  The software workarounds since March  - done under duress and to no apparent outcome (inferring that they never did sufficiently testing of the software in the first place) - infer real engineering and organizational shortcomings. If anything were to go wrong with the CST-100 unmanned launch to ISS (much less a manned flight), it would be  "betting the franchise" in a misguided attempt to "double down" in its attempt to re-establish engineering prominence in flight design and execution. Sales of aircraft could be expected to be cancelled, with untold financial implications.
Seeing that Boeing pushed off the test flight from April to now August reflects a new sense of caution . So I feel caution will continue, and the decision to test a launch to the ISS  (much less to send a man to the ISS) is not going to happen in 2019. On the other hand - published reports say SpaceX is ready for manned flight to the ISS in Dec 2019. Its reusable Falcon Heavy launchers reflect the innovation of its engineers.  However, Space X has cross-ownership in Tesla, a cash-consuming and very leveraged enterprise. Musk owns majority control of both.  Space X raised a billion in fresh capital in May. There is a chance that some of that money gets siphoned to Tesla - which would slow down SpaceX' needed spending. There is also a chance that any Tesla debt offering gets cross-collateralized by SpaceX. So even if their engineering is checks out and is ready - unexpected cash draws are not unimaginable.
But Musk needs a win - and this would be it. 
I don't expect caution is the watchword here. 
And if it turns out badly - I don't see this as a franchise bet for Musk the way I see it with Boeing - thus, more runway.
So I'll rate the chance of a SpaceX manned flight in 2019 (rightly or wrongly) as more that just an incidental probability.

(TL;DR: Looks to me like SpaceX is still in the lead despite the anomaly.) So, we've got some new dates ( https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2019/06/station-planning-new-crew-launch-dates/ ,  HT @dlaiocean ), though apparently not public ones.  How do these compare to the public February ( https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/2019/02/06/nasa-partners-update-commercial-crew-launch-dates/ ) and April ( https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/2019/04/03/nasas-commercial-crew-program-boeing-test-flight-dates-and-spacex-demo-2-update/ ) dates?  On February 6th, the penciled-in schedule for SpaceX was: SpaceX Demo-1 (uncrewed): March 2, 2019
SpaceX In-Flight Abort Test: June 2019
SpaceX Demo-2 (crewed): July 2019 The first succeeded, then there was the static fire test on April 20 that had the anomaly. As of June 17th, the penciled-in schedule for SpaceX is:
SpaceX Demo-2 (crewed): November 15, 2019 ----- On February 6th, the penciled-in schedule for Boeing was: Boeing Orbital Flight Test (uncrewed): No earlier than April 2019
Boeing Pad Abort Test: No earlier than May 2019
Boeing Crew Flight Test (crewed): No earlier than August 2019 On April 3rd, the penciled-in schedule for Boeing was: Boeing Pad Abort Test: Summer 2019
Boeing Orbital Flight Test (uncrewed): August 2019
Boeing Crew Flight Test (crewed): Late 2019 As of June 17th, the penciled-in schedule for Boeing is: Boeing Orbital Flight Test (uncrewed):  17 September 2019
Boeing Crew Flight Test (crewed): 30 November 2019 ----- So.  We knew SpaceX would be delayed by the anomaly, but now we seem to have a solid idea of how delayed -- a previous report put them in "late 2019", and this date is consistent with that and still puts them before Boeing.  Further, we've seen Boeing's schedule just keep slipping.  The uncrewed flight test which we were told could be as soon as in two months in February, and were told would be in four months in April, is now in three months in late June.  I fully expect further slippage, don't you? This is in line with my expectations as of the previous release which suggested the anomaly was something that didn't require a serious change to Crew Dragon ( https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2019/05/nasa-briefly-crew-dragon-anomaly-spacex-schedule/ ).  So, my current doubt about SpaceX making it this year is just not being sure if they really will pass the pad test or in-flight abort test without something that worries NASA.  If they test and pass, I'll move the odds sharply up for them.  My current doubt about Boeing is based on their long history of having schedules slip; I expect more slipping.

Boeing has bigger problems than they let on to.  The 737-MAX issue has uncovered a deeper engineering design problem then they first let on to, and it may cross over into other departments.  The MCAS system is a good example of design-implementation failure:  From design thru implementation Boeing left out past design lessons about redundant systems, input from the 'operators' (Pilots), and training.  We have seen the results of what happens when these processes go missing.  The Space Program is much more complicated and if Boeing did not include past lessons and 'operators' in their design and testing protocols, then they will have to revamp their approach.  That can't be done in just a few months. As for Space X - With the loss of their crew capsule plans will take a serious hit.  Think Gemini Program.  Not that anything went wrong with the Space X capsule itself, but catastrophic issues like this will cause a complete re-look at the program.  These things are really complicated and when things break people can die.  Space X will have to take a very serious look at their operation after the safety report is finished.  Again, this cannot be done in a few months.

SpaceX is developing their Crew Dragon Spacecraft to carry up to seven passengers to and from Earth, and are also planning to use the spacecraft to transport cargo. In March of 2019 the Crew Dragon successfully docked with the International Space Station (ISS) becoming the first US spacecraft to autonomously dock with the orbiting lab (https://www.spacex.com/dragon). However, during a scheduled test this April the spacecraft experienced a fiery anomaly in which plumes of smoke could be seen coming from the testing site (https://www.nbcnews.com/mach/science/spacex-s-crew-dragon-accident-could-delay-first-crewed-flight-ncna997261). SpaceX is expected to conduct one more uncrewed flight of the Crew Dragon to test its emergency abort system, and depending upon its success NASA could authorize the first crewed flight to the International Space Station. Boeing has also been working to develop its CST-100 Starliner to transport up to 7 astronauts to and from the ISS in a completely autonomous spacecraft that is able to withstand land-based returns (https://www.boeing.com/space/starliner/). After several delays and a tight schedule that conflicts with other launches, Boeing plans to conduct their uncrewed flight test in August of 2019 six months after SpaceX's successful docking at the ISS. SpaceX is in the final stages of launching its first crewed space mission in July of this year while Boeing falls short with several delays and scheduling conflicts.

A base rate: SpaceX has had 70 launches. 3 out of these have seen either a failure of some kind or a “partial success”. [1] I am not counting failures related to the landing of the booster rockets (landing the rockets is important for economic viability but is far less relevant for safety, which is why I think it’s a different reference class). That means Space X has had a failure rate of 4 percent.  On the other hand, timing is not guaranteed. Mission delays have been common [2]. However, with the in-flight abort test scheduled for June (with the crewed mission following thereafter), there is somewhat of a buffer until the end of the year. Factors to watch:
- Will NASA require SpaceX to redesign the parachute system? [2] That would delay the current schedule
- Will NASA request to buy more seats from Russia? Currently it has no way to get to ISS and is reportedly considering buying seats on the Russian Soyuz capsule as a hedge. Whether or not NASA does this would signal how it sees the chances of a successful crewed mission with either SpaceX or Boeing. Well, the news is this:  https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/2019/04/03/nasas-commercial-crew-program-boeing-test-flight-dates-and-spacex-demo-2-update/ SpaceX's unmanned test flight, which in February was scheduled for March 2, went ahead and launched March 2.  They're accordingly still on the announced-in-February schedule to make their June in-flight abort test and July manned launch.  A failure on the June test would throw things into doubt, of course.  But they can absorb a five-month delay in the manned flight schedule and still launch before the end of 2019.  SpaceX is likely to succeed. Boeing, on the other hand, has pushed their unmanned test flight, scheduled in February for April, to August.  Their pad abort test, scheduled in February for May, is now "summer 2019".  And their manned mission, originally called in February for August, is now "late 2019".  So all the dates have slipped four months over the last two.  That indicates the February schedule was wildly over-optimistic, which suggests the current schedule may suffer similar over-optimism, meaning the "late 2019" should be treated with skepticism.  And if they have any issues with either of their two tests outstanding, that will likely zero out their chances this year.

Base Case: There is an extensive history of prolonged delays. Just look at how successful either company was in achieving manned spaceflight in 2018. Back in 2014, SpaceX and Boeing both received contracts under NASA's Commercial Crew Development program to build spacecraft that could carry astronauts to the International Space Station. The program is intended to allow NASA to launch astronauts on American spacecraft again, something that hasn't happened since the last flight of the space shuttle in 2011. The spacecraft being developed by SpaceX and Boeing—the Dragon 2 and the CST-100 Starliner, respectively—proved to be more difficult than originally anticipated. Both companies pushed back their plans for 2017 flights to 2018. Elon Musk recently said the Crew Dragon, which is what NASA calls the Dragon 2, is "way more difficult" than the cargo version of the spacecraft that is used to take supplies to the ISS. "As soon as people enter the picture, it's really a giant step up in making sure things go right," said Musk at a recent panel on the commercial crew program. "The oversight from NASA is much tougher." Fortunately, however, the work to achieve flights next year seems to be progressing nicely. NASA along with Boeing and SpaceX have indicated that they are on track to hit target launch dates in 2018. A July 20 report released by NASA shows that SpaceX is still targeting an unmanned test flight in February 2018 and a crewed flight in June 2018, and Boeing is aiming to launch an unmanned test flight in June 2018 and a crewed flight in August 2018. Boeing also plans to conduct pad abort tests in early 2018.

My argument is (loosely) grounded on the time between first unmanned test and first manned test of previous manned spacecrafts: for Vostok 1 it took 11 months, for Mercury 19 months, for Soyuz 6 months and for the Space Shuttle about 19 months, give or take. In general the waiting time should decrease, with the Space Shuttle probably being an exception owing to its complexity. I finally settle for 10 months for both SpaceX and Boeing,  and I expect a variance of 3 months (however there is too much guesstimation going on in these figures). Assuming a one month delay on the test unmanned flight for the Dragon II (SpaceX) and Starliner (Boeing), this puts the peak of the probability distribution for the manned flight 2 and 3 months after January 1st 2020. Assuming a normal distribution of 3 months for the error (very naive), this gives a 25% and 16% probability for Space X and Boeing respectively for launching (and a 4% probability that both will launch before January 1st 2020). The forecast has to be updated to 37% for SpaceX as they have test the Dragon on time, with Boeing still on 16% and the combined probability being 6%.
